attributes.action:
Introduce Joined-Up Water Infrastructure Planning
Tackle Drought and Flood Risk
attributes.additional_details: The UK faces more extreme weather—longer dry spells and heavier rainfall causing flooding. Water infrastructure hasn’t kept pace. Yorkshire’s population has grown by 500,000 since 2000, but no new reservoir has been built since the 1960s. Hosepipe bans are now common, while floodwater and drainage assets remain underused. We need a joined-up national strategy to manage water for both drought and flood resilience—linking reservoirs, canals, floodplains, and quarries into one cohesive system.
attributes.background: Government to require water companies and public agencies to develop a joined-up national strategy for water infrastructure that addresses both drought and flood risk. Investment in reservoirs, sustainable drainage systems, and multi-use water assets such as water courses, quarries, and floodplains.
